Toxicity means removing interaction from the lane. Pantheon does this, by having unavoidable damage as well as unavoidable CC attached to a quick all in. If you get within range you get hurt, if you get within a certain range you get hurt more.

Yasuo's wind wall does remove abilities, but it does not remove the ability to interact. It can be baited, it can be walked through, it can be played around.

Yasuo himself encourages lane interaction. He, as a champion, is well designed because he encourages a tug of war between laners to strip his defenses and kill him before he kills them. It's something both players get to participate in.

He earns a ton of ire because his W is a very large and very clear "!*@& your move" button, which makes it highly emotional, but little more.

TLDR: You may not enjoy Yasuo's kit but, in reality, it's the opposite of toxic. So yeah, you suck and do need to get better.

Windwall is Yasuo's only controllable defensive measure.

Melee having the ability to press a button and heavily negate damage is.. Not unusual. Pretty much every melee has this in the form of a shield, resistance boost, % damage reduction, immunity, or something else. Yasuo is actually bizarre in that his only effects specific abilities, rather than damage in general. For a melee, Yasuo has very little control over his own defenses. This is where the tug of war comes from.

Yasuo's wind wall also has a 26 second cooldown at level one and he's never going to max it first. That's 22 seconds of down time.

To put that in perspective, most forms of ranged crowd control have 10-14 second cooldowns depending on rank.. So it's pretty easy to use the first one to bait the wall, then just engage when it's back up.

I literally don't even play Yasuo; I hate playing squishy divers. More than that he's one of the hardest MU's for one of my favorite champions, Twisted Fate. Despite that I can recognize the strength of his design and have an idea how to play around him. So while I don't always win my lanes against him I do always enjoy them, and always that my deaths in said lane are due to my own errors / the Yasuo players straight up outplaying me.

EDIT:

The "Press W to remove interaction" is fine because of the cooldown, and the fact that you can navigate around it. Yasuo's W does not remove interaction in the way that point-and-click hard CC does, or point and click poke. Simply walking away is an easy and viable option. Live to fight another day, or 10 seconds later when your abilities are back up and he's without his primary defensive method.

Many champions don't have a defensive measure that powerful built into their kit. It's pretty minor in comparison and usually is in a form of some skillshot or has range restriction.

Despite it being partially uncontrollable, Yasuo does have a shield on top of this (that makes support shields weep in despair), making him harder to take out (pressing R instantly gives him a shield). 

Keep in mind, regardless of his higher skill cooldown, any semi-decent Yasuo is going to hold it off until they need to press W. Same as ranged crowd control. Once you blow it out, it's out. They are usually skillshots as well, taking at least a little skill to land it. Whereas Yasuo's is spam W to use. Just because ranged CC has less CD doesn't mean you get to reuse it twice in one battle majority of the time, considering most fights are done and over <10 seconds.  Therefore, his "high cooldown" is pretty negligible for how powerful it is. 

Personally, I don't have an issue fighting against Yasuo (I play Annie and wreck his face all day). However, Yasuo players should admit that their champion has a toxic skill that needs to be addressed, rather than whine about how martyred they are. Considering that he was created by Certaintly, they need to strip a few aspects of kit to make it more in line with the other champions' kit. Fix the W issue and then add power into the rest of his kit to make him feel better to play against as well as play. If they have to do a mini rework, so be it.

Champions are not all built the same, we are talking specifically about melee champions here. Specifically divers, fighters, and light fighters; Yasuo being among their number.

I have a gigantic post I wrote awhile back which breaks down the other champions whom Yasuo shares his role with. They're Trynd, Yi, Fiora, and Aatrox; basically melee ADC's who have been rebranded as 'light fighters'. Among this role all champions have their own differences, but they also have a bare-bones defensive scheme in common.

That being one defensive measure / steroid (in Aatrox case this is healing heavily from offense, and Trynd actually has two) and one untargetable / unkillable measure. All of these champions still have those, though Fiora has begun to mirror Aatrox in that she has offensive healing and a brief immunity.

This is a class of champions which, well, just didn't work very well. They were either abusive and oppressive or.. garbage. One or the other, not in the middle.

Yasuo was designed to work. As a result his 'general' defense was made stronger, but was also made into something he cannot control. He was not given blanket untargetability, but was given a very powerful tool which shared a niche.

Simply saying "Some champions don't have defenses!" is pointless without looking at context. TF and Brand don't have defenses, but both of them are in way better spots than Yasuo. Yasuo's shield is strong as shit, but it's effective cooldown (when not ulting) is far larger than all other shields, and unlike supports it does not come with augments and is purely selfish.


> Keep in mind, regardless of his higher skill cooldown, any semi-decent Yasuo is going to hold it off until they need to press W. Same as ranged crowd control. Once you blow it out, it's out. They are usually skillshots as well, taking at least a little skill to land it. Whereas Yasuo's is spam W to use. Just because ranged CC has less CD doesn't mean you get to reuse it twice in one battle majority of the time, considering most fights are done and over <10 seconds.  Therefore, his "high cooldown" is pretty negligible for how powerful it is. 

This is fine, in fact this is healthy. Remember that tug of war I spoke of? This is not.

Yasuo holding his wall for the right moment, and his enemy trying to bait it out of him / play around it **is healthy and non-toxic gameplay. It is exactly what League needs and exactly what the game is designed for.**

> Personally, I don't have an issue fighting against Yasuo (I play Annie and wreck his face all day). However, Yasuo players should admit that their champion has a toxic skill that needs to be addressed, rather than whine about how martyred they are. Considering that he was created by Certaintly, they need to strip a few aspects of kit to make it more in line with the other champions' kit. Fix the W issue and then add power into the rest of his kit to make him feel better to play against as well as play. If they have to do a mini rework, so be it.

CertainlyT is probably the best designer Riot has.

His champions are the absolute definition of healthy gameplay **from a design perspective.** They all define the champion's strength, make them interact with their enemy laner, and then also throw in reasons and encouragement for them to take further risks and put themselves in harms way for maximum rewards.

His champions also generally come with numbers problems (not unique to him) and, in some cases, a few extra effects which need to be stripped away. But design ideaology wise, he's the best Riot has by leaps and bounds.

If you are talking about melee champions, don't bring in ranged CC's cooldown into the subject matter. Frankly, this is a balance of a champion against 100+. You cannot simply say, "He's melee, so let's only compare him to melee when we want to do balance stuff". Sorry, but that's not going to work. Or else there wouldn't be so many complaints about ADC vs melee. 

It's not healthy to have something that is uncounterable in itself when you have that tug of war. His W counters all projectiles without any given thought. Shields can be broken. Skillshots can be dodged (or outright facetanked). What exactly counters his W outside baiting it out (not going to happen) or pray your champion's kit doesn't have a projectile (good luck in casual/Blind)? 

------
CertainlyT, that you? He's probably one of the worst designers Rito has. Every time he comes up with something by himself, it's usually things that are unbalanceable and unfun to play against. Have him collaborate with others and he does well. By himself, he's a nut. 

Design perspective is one thing, however, real time play is what dictates how well this perspective is implemented. Ideas are just that. Ideas. But when it comes into fruition and turns out to be a nightmare, then you can't exactly say it was healthy to begin with. There has to be a line drawn between ideal and reality and unfortunately, this designer has shown us that he is unable to scale back. If you have to strip back "extra effects", then it wasn't healthy to begin with. There's no use arguing about it because it shouldn't have been brought to the table to begin with. And by that same breath, because you have to strip back these things, he is not the best designer. 

A designer needs to know how to not only look at the champion kit to create something unique, but at the same time, allow it to flourish and fall with the rest of the champion pool. His designs removes those "falls" with failsafes in the kit, allowing them only flourish. And that is where the problem is. Other champions don't have these failsafes as well, which makes them fall under those who do more easily. 

The designer is bad for League because of his design philosphy. He is better off working for DotA because it is there where his designs will shine and not be complained about.

For me, it isn't Yasuo's Wind Wall that kills interactivity.  It's the fact that his E has no limit to the number of dashes, no mana cost, insanely low cooldowns, and can be spammed as often as there are unique minions (and workable directions) within a wave to support it.  A lot of champions just more or less can't interact with that, or damage him nearly at all if he spams Sweeping Blades in and out of a given area - and every really strong Yas player I've ever seen does just that.

He was designed very specifically to counter long-range mages, to break up a very mage-heavy mid meta, all the way back in Season 3 - which he succeeded at beyond his wildest dreams.  He has a spell shield that regenerates, a projectile block, nearly unlimited dashes (at least in and around an enemy wave), and assassin burst damage.  

It's an intensely polarizing kit generally.
